awd_titl_txt: The role of short duration climate events in reducing natural tree regeneration in forests and woodlands of the southwestern United States
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests in the southwestern United States are declining and their future is uncertain. Much previous research focused on how disturbances such as wildfire, insect outbreaks, and severe drought killed mature trees. Yet, young trees are also failing to grow from seed to adulthood in some locations, suggesting that failure of the natural regeneration process may also be important. Changes in temperature and moisture conditions are becoming less favorable for juvenile tree survival. This may lead to even more severe forest ecosystem declines in the future. This project will examine how short duration climate events such as timing of summer rainfall support and limit juvenile tree survival. The role of local environments, and the stress tolerance of juvenile trees has not received substantial research attention. This project will train undergraduate and graduate students, including individuals from under-represented groups. The University of Nevada-Las Vegas is a Minority-Serving Institution. This project will also enhance scientific infrastructure by establishing three vegetation and climate monitoring towers. Research results will be useful to regional forest managers, who will gain critical information for understanding the future of forest ecosystems in the southwestern United States. 

This research will use ground-based field instrumentation and remote sensing to study the specific environmental conditions that initiate juvenile tree mortality events. The three dominant coniferous tree species in the region will be studied: ponderosa pine, pinon pine, and juniper. This instrumentation will be deployed over multiple years and across diverse landscapes in the southwestern U.S. This work hypothesizes that juvenile tree mortality will be caused by environmental conditions that are different and less severe than those determined experimentally. However, it is likely that prolonged environmental stress will be required to kill juvenile trees due to the favorable microclimates where they are located. Additionally, improved mechanistic insight on juvenile tree mortality will be used to enhance existing forecasts of natural forest regeneration in scenarios of 21st century climate change. When completed, this research will improve our understanding of how the interaction of climate, environment, and tree stress tolerance will shape the future of forests in the southwestern U.S.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award Outcomes: The goals of this work were to: a) Develop insight on the detailed, near-surface environmental conditions that influence ponderosa pine reforestation (tree planting) initiatives in different forest settings of the southwestern United States; and b) Install and maintain a network of instrumented climate monitoring stations in woodland and forest ecosystems in Nevada and Arizona. We conducted a 3-year planting experiment in southern Nevada, and installed 11 monitoring stations (7 in Nevada, 4 in Arizona). The planting experiment has elucidated how environmental differences in burned and unburned forest sites limit reforestation success, when and why planted seedlings die, and how slightly longer acclimation periods (as little as 10 days) can greatly improve seedling acclimation and survival. The monitoring stations have supported diverse research projects, including exploration of environmental effects to ponderosa pine physiology and stress tolerance, and estimations of potential patterns of forest and woodland ecosystem change. Southern Nevada and Arizona experience different kinds of hot and dry meteorological and environmental conditions, and can provide a contemporary analog to future conditions that may be experienced in other locations of the western United States. To date, this work has supported 2 peer-reviewed scientific publications, 7 research reports to United States government agencies, and has trained 8 early career scientists. An additional 4 publications are in preparation or planned to be produced from this work in the coming 3 years.

 

Intellectual Merit: This work has developed new insight on near-surface forest environments of the southwestern United States, their effects to planted ponderosa pine seedling survival, and has uncovered a surprising acclimation capacity of ponderosa pine seedlings that increases their stress tolerance. This work is developing long term meteorological and environmental data across forest and woodlands in southern Nevada and central Arizona. These data have been and will continue to be used to conduct research on how environmental conditions are linked to forest and woodland change in the southwestern United States, and how these hot and dry woodlands and forests can provide a contemporary analog to future environmental conditions and ecosystem change that may be experienced in other forests and woodlands of the western United States.

 

Broader Impacts: Ponderosa pine-dominated forests are among the most threatened ecosystems in the western United States. This work produced a simple, science-based strategy for improving ponderosa pine reforestation by increasing the acclimation time of planted seedlings. Additionally, monitoring station data include 6 stations in pinyon pine-juniper woodlands – another threatened ecosystem type that may potentially be federally designated as critical habitat under the Endangered Species Act. This work is continuing to develop diverse and long term data on the environmental conditions in pinyon pine-juniper woodlands, which will be used to better understand their function and future in the southwestern United States. This project provided training for 4 undergraduates, 2 technicians, 1 graduate student, and 1 postdoctoral scholar. 4 trainees were from groups underrepresented in STEM.
